security: Revealing that the CIA directly informed the Mexican President of intentions to overthrow Castro and suggesting that Mexico's help would alleviate the issue of inviting Castro to Mexico could damage international relations and compromise CIA operations. Quoting the document: 'Mr. Scott suggested that if the Mexican President helped CIA to achieve the overthrow of Castro, he would not have to deal with the problem of inviting Castro to Mexico.'
summary: A memorandum detailing a conversation between President Lopez Mateos of Mexico and Mr. Winston Scott, Chief of Station, Mexico, where Lopez Mateos conveyed his friendship to the United States, his invitation to President Dorticos of Cuba, and his decision not to invite Fidel Castro to Mexico.
summary_one_paragraph: On June 9, 1960, J.C. King, Chief of the Western Hemisphere Division, sent a memorandum to the Acting Director of Central Intelligence regarding a conversation between President Lopez Mateos of Mexico and Mr. Winston Scott, Chief of Station, Mexico. Lopez Mateos requested that President Eisenhower be informed of his friendship with the U.S., his reasons for inviting President Dorticos of Cuba, and his resolve not to invite Fidel Castro. Further, Scott suggested that if President Lopez Mateos aided the CIA in overthrowing Castro, he would not need to confront the issue of inviting Castro to Mexico, indicating indirect communication of CIA intentions to the Mexican President.
title: Conversation between President Lopez Mateos of Mexico and Mr. Winston Scott, Chief of Station, Mexico
sender: J. C. King, Chief, Western Hemisphere Division
